bibl.title: Letter from Joseph H. White to Frederick F. Russell, January 8, 1924

div1.p: White writes about his field work to control the spread of yellow fever in Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph H. White to Frederick F. Russell, January 8, 1924
div1.opener:
COPY
DEPARTAMENTO DE SAÚDE PUBLICA
BAHIA, BRASIL
January 8, 1924
COPY
Dear Dr. Russell:
div1.p:
You will be interested to know that the work here is progressing at a
very satisfactory rate, despite propaganda, and that the people are apparently
entirely satisfied. In many instances they ask for fish (of course they are
given) and I think the anti-fish campaign will die a natural death in a few
weeks more.

We found yellow fever for Noguchi in the village of Bella Palmyra
west of here one day by rail and then by mule and altho it is not necessary
I have sent a man, Dr. Studart, out there, to please the Brazilians and he
can temporize with it until it dies out - I doubt if he does much more than that.

It probably got there from Lincon just above the rail head and Lincon
was infected from Bahia last summer and I understand has now smoldered out or
nearly so. Lincon has 10,000 and Bella Palmyra 3,000 inhabitants.

Of course we will probably meet a dozen or so of such temporary and
localized flares and I am sorry to say that here as in Mexico they seem to
cause more consternation than the big cities.

Scannell starts soon for a trip up to Para and intermediate points
while I stay here and I think he will leave Ormachia at Pernambuco as I am
doubtful about the capacity of Walcott to get his machine well organized and
moving strongly and smoothly at the same time. He gets the good will of the
local men but we need much more than that so in as much as Pernambuco is a
large center I am justified in putting in an extra man (a tremendous worker)
without having to explain anything.

I shall later cover the whole circuit myself but just now, feel that
-2-
this place must be very carefully held - not from the mosquito standpoint, but
the standpoint of medical politics, of which there is plenty.

Noguchi has gotten his new strain and was adroit enough to have a Bra-
ailian find it first, then demonstrate to all the Professors in the local medical
school.

He now says he can't finish here and go to Pernambuco before February
21, in which case I told him he probably would find nothing there and would just
as well go on to Ceara to get the data he wants and thence to Para where he can
get the Booth Line to N.Y.

I hope Chagas comes up on 16th with Dr. Frazu, the Bahia congressman
on whom he (Chagas) is relying to straighten out matters here. They need no at-
tention now as since he would not come we have helped ourselves and he will on
arrival find nothing to do but to open his eyes and see for himself that the work
is done - well done, and the people content. That sort of thing is so unusual
here that he will find it hard to believe.

We simply sat steady, never answered a word of criticism, were courteous
to all, redoubled our precautions and won the people to our side.

Finally our sharpost critic, Prof. Valladam, comes out and says that
while he “never wanted the Yankees here because Brazilians are able (?) and will-
ing (?) to help themselves, they should be treated courteously and respectfully
hecause the man who thinks these Yankees don't know their business most thoraly,
is a fool.”
We are still running about 7% and the larvae met are 90% stegs.

I am beginning to suspect that this is the place that re-infected Africa
(4 days away) was she ever was clean, and I want to make some maps and study my
data with great care - but that is another story and subject matter for another
letter.
